intro: Dicliptera knappiae, commonly known as the Knapp's dicliptera, is a flowering plant native to specific regions of South America. It belongs to the grass family (Poaceae) and is characterized by its tufted growth habit and slender, wiry stems. The plant produces small, spike-like inflorescences that bear numerous tiny florets, typical of grasses. Its leaves are narrow and often have a hairy texture, contributing to its distinctive appearance. Dicliptera knappiae is adapted to arid or semi-arid environments, showcasing resilience to drought conditions.
